Alcoholics Anonymous is once again at the center of an impassioned debate over addiction treatment programs.

This latest round was sparked by an article in the April issue of The Atlantic magazine titled ""The Irrationality Of Alcoholics Anonymous."" In it, Gabrielle Glaser writes this - nowhere in the field of medicine is treatment less grounded in modern science.

And she argues that there's new urgency to examining and questioning AA and other 12-step programs given that the Affordable Care Act has greatly expanded coverage for alcohol and substance abuse treatment.
Gabrielle Glaser joins us now.
Thank you for being here.
Thanks for having me.
Now, in explaining how AA became dominant in treating alcohol dependence in the U.S., you actually point to its history.
And you say not a lot was known about the brain when AA was founded 80 years ago.
Right.
And we did a lot of things in 1935 that we don't do anymore.
We - you know, when babies were delivered, we spanked them on the bottom and held them upside-down.
And that's something that didn't necessarily hurt babies, but we don't do that anymore.
And I'm not saying that AA shouldn't exist.
But what I am saying is that we can't prove its efficacy.
And some of the studies that have been done just don't justify our immense reliance on a system that hasn't been found to be effective.
Can you expand on this idea of immense reliance?
Just how predominate is AA and 12-step ideology in the substance treatment world?
It is very predominant.
There was a book that came out in 2013 called ""Inside Rehab"" by Anne Fletcher.
And that book found that up to 80 percent of all rehabs rely on AA and 12-step treatments as the foundation for their centers.
Now, you write that no conclusive data exists on how well AA works.
And this has been challenged by critics who say that there is research out there at there, at least on something called the 12-step facilitation programs, which actually prepare people for AA.
Correct.
Twelve-step facilitation is a form of therapy that's done with a licensed therapist aiming to get a person into AA.
It's not the same as AA itself.
AA meetings are held mostly in church basements by leaders who are not necessarily trained.
Anybody can start an AA meeting.
Anybody can be in AA.
And that's not the same as a licensed therapist.

The counterargument to this is that, you know, some of what is effective about AA - peer support or spirituality or the idea of personal transformation - doesn't exactly lend itself to scientific metrics.
Right.
And I note that in the piece.
I note that that's a benefit that people do get from being in a group such as AA.
But there are also many others that are free and peer-led, and they happen to be rooted in evidence-based treatment.
Many of them use cognitive behavioral therapy as their backbone.
One is Smart Recovery.
Moderation Management is another one.
And Women for Sobriety is a third.

What's your response to people who say that the way you're talking about this is in some ways irresponsible - that you're letting people off the hook who should be fighting their addiction, that you're endangering treatment in some way?
My response to that is that this treatment actually can be just as damaging and dangerous for people for whom it's failing.
AA doesn't refer anybody out.
It doesn't tell anybody that AA is not for them.
It's very unlike other professional organizations which refer people to second opinions.
AA tells people that if they don't benefit, it's basically their fault.
This has produced, really, a lot of tragedies.
I hear about them all the time.
I hear about them weekly.
Someone sent me an email this morning about a younger brother who committed suicide last night with the Big Book and a glass of scotch next to his bed.
It causes people to blame themselves for failing and consequently spending more time in the program feeling worse about themselves.
Families also blame their loved ones if they don't do well or if they drop out, rather than realizing that AA may not be the best approach.
In terms of the alternatives you write about in your article, one would be a prescription drug that helps people learn to drink in moderation.
I'm sure there are people who would say using a drug to treat someone with alcohol addiction doesn't really make a lot of sense.
That is an idea that's kind of rooted in history.
When doctors were trying to get people away from their alcohol addiction in the 1950s and 1960s, they were also prescribing Valium.
So many people would become addicted both to Valium and to alcohol.
This is a completely different drug.
Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist.
It's non-addicting.
It's been shown in dozens and dozens of studies to be very safe.
And in Finland, it's used for drinkers to learn to moderate.
The drug is legal.
It was approved by the FDA in 1994.
And it's used here only about 1 percent of cases.
So there's a whole kit of tools out there that have been ignored.
And this is really the moment to have this conversation.
As you've said, the Affordable Care Act now covers treatment for people with alcohol use disorder.
The question arises - what treatments are we going to cover?
What are we going to invest in as we move forward?
Gabrielle Glaser - she wrote the piece ""The Irrationality Of Alcoholics Anonymous"" that appears in the April issue of The Atlantic.
Thank you so much for speaking with us.
Thank you so much for having me.
